text: if you're gonna spend some time in San
Francisco and you have a limited amount
of time one good way to get into the
city is to start at the water San
Francisco as is famously known as
surrounded by water you might want to
start off at places along Ocean Beach
which is the kind of majestic Pacific
Rim which is home to the Cliff House was
a classic old-school San Francisco
establishments been there for over a
hundred years the view is absolutely
unbeatable and with two stories of
restaurants it's really a must-see
location right along the Pacific as well
is the ocean in Beach LA which is a pair
of restaurants one of which has a
terrific Sunday brunch and then of
course there's just Ocean Beach which in
and of itself is kind of a great San
Francisco tradition bonfires are kind of
a steady thing there on the weekends
other locations along the Pacific edge I
would include the Sunset District which
has long been considered kind of a
sleepy backwater but in the last say 10
or 15 years has really become a kind of
a hipsters paradise there's a collection
of little bistros and coffee shops and
even surf shops in addition Golden Gate
Park is kind of a hidden jewel I don't
think many people actually visiting the
city end up there but it's actually
bigger than Central Park and it's got a
wide variety of activities you can do
everything from watch a group of bison
there's a big bison pen there there's a
nine-hole three-part Golf Course then
there's also the the fly casting ponds
which is kind of great old throwback
it's a nice place to spend an afternoon
even if you're not a fisherman you can
sit there and read a book one of my
favorite spots is right there along the
Pacific there's a spot called Sutro
Heights Sutra was a mover and shaker in
San Francisco in the 19th century and
his family has continued to be an
influential in the city into the 20th he
developed a series of public baths right
there along specific they failed fell
into disrepair and eventually were
demolished but you can still see the
relics there and from Sutro Heights
which overlooks that it's a great spot
to kind of get a sense of the history of
San Francisco as well as the the initial
appeal why people ended up here the
immense physical beauty for anyone
looking for another good cheap and and
certainly scenic location the Presidio
of San Francisco which were
long time was a military base is is
really one of the most scenic and kind
of untapped resources any Goldsworthy
who's kind of a well-known landscape
artist has done a couple of
environmental sculptures up there one of
which is called spire which is
particularly striking wooden spy kind of
shooting skyward right near there are
some of the best views of the bay
a nice brisk walk along Crissy Field
which is the right underneath the Golden
Gate Bridge it's pretty much an
unbeatable location you've got sweeping
views not only the bay but of the Marin
Headlands in the distance on a clear day
you can actually really see forever in
San Francisco so a good cheap treat is
just to wonder along the waterfront
